subject: JUnit Exception Test Advice
msgSnippet: Hello, this is not a question but a petition for advice from seasoned testers like you ;). Normally you write JUnit tests for exception like this:
messageBody:
Hello, this is not a question but a petition for advice from seasoned
testers like you ;).

Normally you write JUnit tests for exception like this:

@Test(expected=NullPointerException.class)

This tells JUnit that if the given exception is not thrown then the
unit test fails. But what happens when you may be expecting different
exceptions in different parts of the test, for example letÂ´s say you
want to connect to a database so first you test with a bad connection
string and you are expecting a SQLException. Then you test with other
connection string and you are not expecting that exception but a
succesful connection instead.

This usually would mean that you have to write two test cases one for
the expected exception and one for the successful connection right?

But what if:

try
{
connection = DriverManager.getConnection(badConnString);
fail("SQLException Expected but was not thrown");
}
catch(SQLException sEx) { }

try
{
connection = DriverManager.getConnection(goodConnString);
}
catch(SQLException sEx)
{
fail(SQLException was not expected but was thrown");
}

----
Is this a valid practice or should be avoided? Would you say that is
better to write separate test cases?
